summary: Pepper...and Salt

summary: Financial-technology company Riskalyze is inviting registered investment advisers to share stories of lousy investment portfolios, writes RIABiz.

summary: What's News: World-Wide

summary: The New Zealand dollar was trading lower against the U.S. dollar late Thursday, still hurt by jawboning from the Reserve Bank of New Zealand Wednesday and after the Federal Open Market Committee meeting minutes weighed on sentiment across Asia.

headline: Where There's a Goal, There's Patrik Elias
summary: Elias has assisted on 35.7% of the Devils' goals this season, the third-highest rate in the NHL.

headline: Shia LaBeouf Bolts 'Orphans'
summary: The 26-year-old film actor had been set to star opposite Alec Baldwin in Lyle Kessler's "Orphans" at the Schoenfeld Theatre. But on Wednesday, producers of the play said that Mr. LaBeouf had withdrawn from the production.

headline: This Greek Reality TV Show Eschews a Grecian Formula
summary: 'Hellenic Home Hunting' follows jet-setting prospects touring Greece in search of the perfect pied-à-terre or villa. But there is a hitch: the program isn't being shown in Greece.

summary: Sony moved to reinvent its PlayStation videogame console, demonstrating faster, graphics-rich hardware with new Internet-based features.

summary: This weekend marks the fifth Kairos Global Summit in New York City, a kind of Ted conference, taking place in part at the Midtown Yotel hotel, for 350 college-age entrepreneurs and 150 world leaders and CEOs.

headline: Costumes and Crystal Crocodiles
summary: After the Oscars take place on Sunday, there won't be many more immediate opportunities to hear another one of Anne Hathaway's bizarre, self-conscious and totally amazing speeches.

headline: The All-Star Break Is Over, Right?
summary: Pacers demolish the frustrated Knicks by 34 points in the team's first game back after the All-Star Break.

headline: Federal Furloughs Likely to Hit by April
summary: More than one million federal employees would likely be forced to take unpaid leave beginning in April as part of a widespread reduction in spending set to start next month barring congressional intervention.

headline: Small Businesses Puzzle Over Tax Strategy
summary: Small-business owners can't change the tax code, but many of them say they might change the way their businesses are structured to pay less tax.

summary: Brazil and Russia moved ahead on high-level talks Wednesday to resolve nagging farm-trade differences, while opening a dialogue that could lead to Brazilian purchases of defense technology.

summary: Railway porters rally against the government in India, soldiers drink snake blood in a drill in Thailand, an orangutan rests in an enclosure in the Singapore Zoo and more.

headline: Landlords Prefer Deals Like Office Depot-OfficeMax to Liquidations
summary: The U.S. shopping-center industry doesn't love the idea of an Office Depot Inc. merger with OfficeMax Inc., but landlords see it as preferable to the risks if the chains don't do something to bulk up.

summary: New programs are helping to guide small-business owners across New York City through the process of retrofitting, convincing those who run bodegas and boutiques to make difficult investments in energy-saving technologies.

headline: Dolan Preps for Pope Vote
summary: Cardinal Timothy Dolan said he was praying as he prepared for his first conclave. He has also been advised to pack some peanut butter.

headline: Culture Count: No Sleep Till Fairyland

headline: Lew's Path To Confirmation Becomes Clearer

headline: The Oscars' Outside Man

headline: Factual Fantasies and Seductive Celluloid

summary: The CEO of Atlas Copco, a Swedish industrial giant, sees American manufacturing, helped by low energy costs and favorable labor environment, as a growing alternative to sending work to Asia.

headline: Regulator May Ban Corzine From Trading
summary: The National Futures Association Thursday is expected to discuss the possibility of banning Jon S. Corzine for life from the futures industry,

headline: The Brainy Side of Fashion

summary: Ralph Gardner Jr. returns to the 19th Precinct stationhouse on the Upper East Side, where he covered crime through most of the 1990s and ending around 2006.

headline: Carlyle Investors Hear the Starting Gun
summary: Ahead of the Tape:  Jaded investors have started believing in private equity again. Shares of Carlyle Group have surged 41% this year. This reflects a strong 2012 and hopes for a coming buyout boom.

headline: Nash Is Missing, and So Is the Rangers' Pace

summary: Chesapeake Energy said a board probe of departing CEO McClendon's personal financial dealings found "no intentional misconduct."

summary: Low interest rates are spurring U.K. insurers to make real-estate loans in an effort to improve investment returns.

summary: Designers are giving islands more features, turning what had been a humble seating annex into a command-and-control center.

summary: A Queen Anne Victorian being used as a bed and breakfast, with eight bedrooms and eight full bathrooms, is on the market in Cloverdale for $1.249 million.

headline: Taxes Can Help; This One Doesn't
summary: Re: your editorial "A Buckeye Tax Reform" (Feb. 12) It seems illogical to levy additional tax burdens on the very industry that has demonstrated the greatest potential for job creation, capital investment and revenue growth.

headline: WTO Candidate: Stalled Talks Put Group at Risk
summary: The World Trade Organization's failure to advance a global round of trade talks is putting the group's role at risk, said Roberto Carvalho de Azevêdo, a career diplomat who is running as Brazil's candidate to take over as head of the institution.

headline: Gold Leads a Retreat Amid Rash of Selling
summary: Gold slumped to a seven-month low, extending its earlier losses as details from the Fed's latest policy meeting outlined more debate about when to curtail the central bank's stimulus program.

headline: At the Fed, Some Must Like It Hot
summary: our editorial "Rumors of (Currency) War" (Feb. 14) is right on. In a fiat-money floating exchange-rate system, governments can manipulate the external value of their currencies simply by their choice of domestic monetary policies.

headline: The WHO Supports India's Fight Against MDR-TB
summary: I was quoted in the article "Global TB Fight Hits a Wall" (Page One, Feb. 16) in a way that implies the World Health Organization is critical of the work of the Revised National TB Control Program of India. This isn't the case.

headline: The Second Amendment and the First Have Limitations
summary: Regarding David B. Rivkin Jr. and Andrew M. Grossman's "Gun Control and the Constitution" (op-ed, Feb. 11): The argument that an individual needs a large capacity magazine for his weapon in order to defend his life and property from multiple attackers is fatuous.

headline: Nymex Crude Falls to One-Month Low
summary: U.S. crude futures dropped 2.3% on a sharp bout of midmorning selling that also pulled down gasoline prices as some investors grow concerned that high prices at the pump could crimp demand.

headline: The View From North Mali
summary: By Anne Jolis  "We weren't even expecting the French to come. We were expecting the Americans."

headline: John Boehner: The President Is Raging Against a Budget Crisis He Created

summary: Japan Prime Minister Shinzo Abe wants to show President Obama that he has the clout and endurance to strengthen economic and security ties.

summary: For decades we've been warned about the dangers of overpopulation. The real threat to our future, argues Jonathan V. Last, is that we are not having enough babies. William McGurn reviews "What to Expect When No One's Expecting."

headline: Don't Get Caught in the REIT of the Moment
summary: As they have reached for yield, many investors have reached for real-estate investment trusts. But in the stampede, they have reached for some more than others.

summary: Responding to the takeover of rival Heinz, which is expected to get leaner, Campbell Soup said it would continue its cost cutting.

headline: Michael Auslin: An Open Letter to Shinzo Abe
summary: Dear Prime Minister: Please inform the U.S. that Japan under your watch will be open, bold and well-armed.

summary: Brazil's real weakened following a report that foreign-exchange flows remained negative through the first 15 days of February.

summary: Minutes of the Fed's latest policy meeting showed that officials worried the central bank's easy-money policies could lead to instability in financial markets.

summary: Suddenly it is the U.K.'s turn in the global spotlight, and markets are becoming increasingly nervous. The U.K. can't afford to lose the confidence of foreign investors.

headline: A Job Too Big Even for Dimon
summary: The argument for stripping even J.P. Morgan Chase Chairman and CEO James Dimon of one of his titles, and for similar change at other big banks, is credible.

headline: Obama, Rubio Put Higher Education on Notice
summary: President Obama and Republican Sen. Marco Rubio want to change the way Washington decides which colleges are eligible for the $175 billion a year the federal government spends on grants, loans and tax breaks for students, David Wessel writes.

headline: Anadarko Sets Capital Spending Limit at $7.6 Billion

headline: Merkel Calls Euro Rate 'Normal'
summary: German Chancellor Angela Merkel appeared to play down concerns that the euro is overvalued and cautioned against any international efforts to devalue currencies in order to boost exports.

headline: Fearful Time for Gold

summary: Swedish auto maker Volvo Car said it would expand cost-cutting efforts to eliminate about 1,000 jobs and $237 million in costs by year-end to stem losses.

summary: Playboy in the past few years has outsourced much of its media operations and shed some of the seedier aspects of its business, like its cable-TV channels, to focus on fragrance licensing and other revenue streams.

summary: The head of a Japanese air-safety organization looking into battery problems on a Boeing 787 said investigators will expand the scope of their search to include the jet's circuit wiring.

summary: The freshman Republican from Texas is emerging as another conservative that the liberal press loves to hate.

summary: British stocks gained as hope mounted for more monetary-policy easing by the Bank of England, but markets elsewhere in Europe edged lower.

headline: Bulgaria's Government Resigns
